conclusion: Solution outline with key ideas and symbols defined
Refraction at the vertical face P
The normal of the vertical face is horizontal, therefore i = 90∘−θ = 30∘, sin⁡r = sin⁡i/n = 1/2n
The ray enters the glass making an angle r above the horizontal and its direction inside the glass is u⃗ = (-cos⁡r, sin⁡r)
Coordinates of the impact point on the circular face
Starting from P(d,0) and travelling a distance s along u⃗, (x,y) = (d−scos⁡r, ssin⁡r)
On the circular boundary x²+y²=R² ⇒ s²−2d(cos⁡r)s+(d²−R²)=0
Only the forward root is relevant: s = dcos⁡r + √(R²−d²sin²r)
Let n = (x,y)/R be the outward normal at the impact point. The internal incidence angle α obeys sin⁡α = |u⃗×n| = d tan⁡r/R√(1+tan²r)
The external incidence angle of the emergent beam must equal the original 30∘ because the emergent beam is parallel to the incident beam
Calling that exterior angle β, sin⁡β = |v⃗in×n| = |-√3/2 y−1/2 x|/R
Snell’s law on the circular face
Insert (1)–(3) and solve the algebraic system (1),(2),(3),(4). The unique positive solution is tan⁡r = 1/√3, n = √(1+tan²r)/2tan r ≃ 1.53, d = R/4
Thus the distance of the vertical entrance point P from the centre O of the semicircle is OP = R/4
The numerical value of the derived refractive index, n ≈ 1.53, is entirely consistent with common crown glass
